Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Ellery Ames of University of Oregon to conduct a research project, entitled "Mathematical methods for understanding gravity near big-bang type events," during the summer of 2012 at University of Otago in Dunedin, NZ. The host scientist is Florian Beyer.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to investigate long-standing questions in gravitational theory regarding the early universe and to develop mathematical techniques to aid in these investigations.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
General relativity (GR) is the most widely accepted theory of gravitation today, and one of the more interesting applications of this theory is to the universe as a whole. Indeed, one of first explicit solutions of the Einstein equations (the equations of GR) describes a homogeneous and isotropic universe much like ours. This solution is singular in a specific sense, and colloquially one says it has a "big-bang." Originally it was thought that this big-bang singularity was due to the high symmetry of the solution, and more general and hence realistic solutions would not contain such singularities. However, it has been proved by Hawking and Penrose that solutions to the Einstein equations are singular under very weak conditions, making singularities the rule rather than the exception. Still, the general behavior of solutions near the singularities is poorly understood.

The program supported by this grant utilizes an analytical scheme called the “Fuchsian method” for proving rigorously that a family of solutions has a certain behavior. Numerical simulations indicate that certain families of solutions behave near the singularity in a way such that roughly the time derivative terms in the Einstein equations dominate over the spatial derivate terms; this behavior is called asymptotically velocity term dominated (AVTD). Fuchsian methods by their nature are especially well suited for proving and analytically investigating this behavior. Understanding the behavior of singular solutions to the fully general Einstein equations is difficult, and the general program of research, including that supported by this EAPSI fellowship, is to study the singular behavior under some symmetry assumptions.

The research supported by this EAPSI fellowship contributes to this research program in the following ways:
(I) A new existence and uniqueness theorem for a class of Fuchsian partial differential equations has been formulated and proved. This theorem is broad enough to cover the Einstein equations with a low degree of symmetry.
 (II) We have developed the necessary mathematical structures for showing that families of spacetimes with very little symmetry (for example one symmetry direction) are AVTD. In addition to the theorem listed in (i) we have developed a scheme for making a choice of time (time is not pre-defined in GR), which is suitable for proving AVTD behavior of spacetimes with low symmetry.
 (III) We have developed an approach for investigating the dependence of AVTD behavior on the choice of time, and have applied this approach in a simple class of solutions to the Einstein equations.
